prompt:
Is the person who wrote this in the wrong in the following situation?

"""
AITA because I want my hair fixed, for free, by the hairdresser?
[What I showed her](http://imgur.com/KmuiLRL)


[What I got](http://imgur.com/gEiWAi4)


I asked my stylist to do a light brown rose gold, and emphasized that I wanted it a light brown, warm color.

I showed her the picture more than a week in advance of the appointment so she had time to get any colors she didn’t have. 

I told her multiple times I wanted a light brown.  I know you can’t perfectly match the picture, but I think I made it obvious I wanted more brown than red in my hair.  I would have been fine without the rose tint.  My hair was bleach blonde to begin with.

She’s going to try to fix it but I don’t think I should have to pay, this is clearly not what I asked for.  Am I the asshole?
"""

Is the author in the wrong? Answer A for Yes (the author is in the wrong) and B for No (the author is not in the wrong). Answer nothing else.

thinking.text:
Okay, so the user is asking whether the person who posted this situation is in the wrong. Let me break it down.

The person went to a hairdresser and showed them a picture of a light brown rose gold color. They emphasized wanting a light brown, warm color and mentioned their hair is bleach blonde. They also told the stylist multiple times about the color preference. The result was something more red than brown, which they're unhappy with. The question is if they're wrong to expect a free fix.

First, the client clearly communicated their request. They showed a reference image a week in advance and repeated their preference. The stylist, on the other hand, didn't match the requested color. Even if the stylist couldn't perfectly replicate the picture, the client's main point was more brown than red. If the result is too red, that's a deviation from the agreed-upon request. 

Hair salons typically include a satisfaction guarantee for color, especially when using references. Clients aren't expected to pay for mistakes caused by the stylist not meeting the agreed-upon result. The client is within their rights to request a complimentary fix. The stylist's error here isn't the client's fault, so the client isn't in the wrong. Answer B.
